author: freep.com
title: Upcoming movies: '99 Homes,' 'Pan,' 'Freeheld'
text: MORE OCT. 9 “Freeheld”: New Jersey police officer Laurel Hester and her registered domestic partner battle to secure Hester’s pension benefits when she is diagnosed with terminal cancer. With Ellen Page and Julianne Moore. Rated PG-13 for mature themes, language and sexuality. “Goodnight Mommy”: When their mother comes home in bandages after cosmetic surgery, twin brothers living in a remote house discover that nothing is as it was before. They soon begin to doubt that the woman living in their house is their mother. Rated R for disturbing and violent content and nudity. “He Named Me Malala”: Documentary about Pakistani schoolgirl Malala Yousafzai, who was attacked by the Taliban for speaking out about the education of girls and later spoke about her ordeal before the United Nations. Rated PG-13 for mature themes, disturbing images and threats. “99 Homes”: A man goes to work for the ruthless real estate broker who evicted him and his family from their home. Andrew Garfield, Michael Shannon and Laura Dern star. Rated R for language, sexual references and a violent image. “Pan”: “Peter Pan” prequel of sorts tells the story of an orphan who is spirited away to magical Neverland, where he discovers fun, danger and ultimately his destiny: to become the hero who will be forever known as Peter Pan. With Hugh Jackman, Garrett Hedlund and Levi Miller. Rated PG for fantasy action violence, language and some mature themes. OCT. 16 “Beasts of No Nation”: Drama based on the experiences of a child soldier fighting in the civil war of an unidentified African country. With Idris Elba. Not rated. “Bridge of Spies”: An American lawyer is recruited by the CIA during the Cold War to help rescue Francis Gary Powers, a U.S. pilot detained in the Soviet Union. Steven Spielberg directs Tom Hanks, Alan Alda and Amy Ryan. Rated PG-13 for violence and language. “Crimson Peak”: Ghost story from director Guillermo del Toro about an aspiring author who is haunted by a childhood tragedy. After she marries a mysterious stranger and moves into his home, she makes a frightening discovery. Charlie Hunnam, Jessica Chastain and Tom Hiddleston star. Rated R for violence, sexual content and language. “Goosebumps”: Action comedy about a teen who teams up with the daughter of a young-adult horror author after the writer’s imaginary demons are set free on a small Maryland town. Jack Black stars. Rated PG for scary action and images and rude humor. “Steve Jobs”: Michael Fassbender stars in biopic about the visionary founder of Apple Inc. Rated R for language. OCT. 23 “Burnt”: A chef (Bradley Cooper) who destroyed his career with drugs and diva-like behavior cleans up his act and returns to London determined to create a restaurant that can gain three Michelin stars. Not yet rated. “Jem and the Holograms”: As a small-town girl catapults from underground video sensation to global superstar, she and her sisters discover that some talents are too special to keep hidden. With Molly Ringwald and Juliette Lewis. Rated PG for reckless behavior, suggestive content and language. “The Last Witch Hunter”: Action fantasy about a man who is all that stands between humanity and the combined forces of the most horrifying witches in history. Vin Diesel stars with Elijah Wood, Michael Caine and Rose Leslie. Rated PG-13 for fantasy violence and frightening images. “Paranormal Activity: The Ghost Dimension”: The long-lived creepy franchise returns just in time for Halloween. Not yet rated. “Rock the Kasbah”: Comedy about a down-on-his-luck music manager who discovers a teen girl with an extraordinary voice while on a music tour in Afghanistan. Bill Murray, Bruce Willis and Zooey Deschanel star. Not yet rated. OCT. 30 “Our Brand Is Crisis”: Comedy-drama about a team of political strategists who employ U.S.-style campaign tactics during a 2002 presidential election in Bolivia. The film is a fictionalized account of a 2005 documentary of the same name. Sandra Bullock and Billy Bob Thornton star. Not yet rated. “Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse”: On the eve of their last camping adventure, three scouts discover the true meaning of friendship when they attempt to save their town from a zombie outbreak. With Patrick Schwarzenegger and Cloris Leachman. Rated R for zombie violence and gore, sexual content, nudity and language. “Suffragette”: Carey Mulligan, Helena Bonham Carter and Meryl Streep star in story about members of the British women’s suffrage movement in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Rated PG-13 for violence, mature themes, language and partial nudity. “Truth”: Newsroom drama about the 2004 “60 Minutes” report investigating then-President George W. Bush’s military service and the subsequent firestorm of criticism that cost anchor Dan Rather (Robert Redford) and producer Mary Mapes (Cate Blanchett) their careers at CBS. Rated R for language and a nude photo. NOV. 6 “Brooklyn”: A young Irish immigrant (Saoirse Ronan) navigates her way through 1950s Brooklyn, N.Y., and eventually finds herself being forced to choose between her old world and her new life. Rated PG-13 for language and a scene of sexuality. “Carol”: Big-screen adaptation of Patricia Highsmith’s novel “The Price of Salt” follows two women from very different backgrounds who find themselves in an unexpected love affair in 1950s New York. Cate Blanchett and Rooney Mara star. Rated R for language and a scene of sexuality and nudity. “Miss You Already”: Drew Barrymore and Toni Collette star in story about the friendship between two lifelong girlfriends and the test it endures when one starts a family and the other falls ill. Rated PG-13 for mature themes, sexual content and language. “The Peanuts Movie”: The beloved comic strip lives again in a new animated adventure with an all-new voice cast of kids. Rated G. “Room”: After 5-year-old Jack and his mother escape from the enclosed surroundings the boy has known his entire life, Jack makes a thrilling discovery: the outside world. As he experiences it, he holds tight to his bond with his devoted mom. Brie Larson, Joan Allen and William H. Macy star. Rated R for language. “Spectre”: A cryptic message from the past sends James Bond (Daniel Craig) on a quest to seek out a sinister organization and reveal the terrible truth behind it. Rated PG-13 for action, violence, disturbing images, sensuality and language.
